DataElement.preferredName: Adverse Event Iobenguane Infusion Procedure Interrupted Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Indicator of whether MIBG infusion was interrupted due to adverse event occurrence.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Adverse Event Iobenguane Infusion Procedure Drug Interrupted
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any unfavorable or unintended disease, sign, or symptom (including an abnormal laboratory finding) that is temporally associated with the use of a medical treatment or procedure, and that may or may not be considered related to the medical treatment or procedure. Such events can be related to the intervention, dose, route of administration, patient, or caused by an interaction with another drug(s) or procedure(s)._A synthetic, aralkylguanidine analogue of the adrenergic neurotransmitter norepinephrine (NE) and adrenergic neuron blocking agent with potential diagnostic imaging or antineoplastic activity when radiolabeled. Iobenguane, also known as metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG), is taken up and accumulates in the granules of adrenal medullary chromaffin cells and in the pre-synaptic granules of adrenergic neurons in a manner almost identical with that of NE. In radiolabeled forms, iobenguane may be used to image or eradicate neuroendocrine tissues and tumor cells._A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream._An indication that a medication schedule was modified by temporarily terminating a prescribed regimen of medication.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any unfavorable or unintended disease, sign, or symptom (including an abnormal laboratory finding) that is temporally associated with the use of a medical treatment or procedure, and that may or may not be considered related to the medical treatment or procedure. Such events can be related to the intervention, dose, route of administration, patient, or caused by an interaction with another drug(s) or procedure(s).:A synthetic, aralkylguanidine analogue of the adrenergic neurotransmitter norepinephrine (NE) and adrenergic neuron blocking agent with potential diagnostic imaging or antineoplastic activity when radiolabeled. Iobenguane, also known as metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG), is taken up and accumulates in the granules of adrenal medullary chromaffin cells and in the pre-synaptic granules of adrenergic neurons in a manner almost identical with that of NE. In radiolabeled forms, iobenguane may be used to image or eradicate neuroendocrine tissues and tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: Any unfavorable or unintended disease, sign, or symptom (including an abnormal laboratory finding) that is temporally associated with the use of a medical treatment or procedure, and that may or may not be considered related to the medical treatment or procedure. Such events can be related to the intervention, dose, route of administration, patient, or caused by an interaction with another drug(s) or procedure(s).

A synthetic, aralkylguanidine analogue of the adrenergic neurotransmitter norepinephrine (NE) and adrenergic neuron blocking agent with potential diagnostic imaging or antineoplastic activity when radiolabeled. Iobenguane, also known as metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG), is taken up and accumulates in the granules of adrenal medullary chromaffin cells and in the pre-synaptic granules of adrenergic neurons in a manner almost identical with that of NE. In radiolabeled forms, iobenguane may be used to image or eradicate neuroendocrine tissues and tumor cells.

Property.preferredDefinition: A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream.:An indication that a medication schedule was modified by temporarily terminating a prescribed regimen of medication.

Concepts.definition: Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord.
An indication that a medication schedule was modified by temporarily terminating a prescribed regimen of medication.

any unfavorable symptoms, signs, or disease temporally associated with the use of a medical
treatment or procedure that may or may not be considered related to the medical
treatment or procedure.
